posts.name: John Naulty
posts.cooked:
Hello Forum, I am a user of Centos/Fedora and would like to help people build rpms

This is my first attempt at a ‚Äòcontribution‚Äô for Signal‚Ä¶so here it goes.

I submitted a PR to build rpms: Add rpm package creation to package.json scripts by jnaulty ¬∑ Pull Request #1627 ¬∑ signalapp/Signal-Desktop ¬∑ GitHub

I‚Äôm not a javascript developer, but I was able to tweak the packages.json to at least produce an rpm and not error out when running on centos (by default this build system will produce a debian package, which means by default this will not work on centos).

I was able to build an rpm for the Desktop App on a Centos 7.4 machine with Node v6.11.5

  • Check out repo: git clone -b dev-rpm-build https://github.com/jnaulty/Signal-Desktop.git
  • Run npm install
  • Run npm run dist-rpm (for building rpm)

posts.cooked:
Linux desktop support is the biggest pain, because ‚Äúevery‚Äù Linux distro has its own packaging. I see two options:

  1. Write how to make package from source. Package maintainers can build packages for other users.
  2. Decide for some modern multi distro package system like: AppImage, Flatpack or Snap. It can still be discussion which one‚Ä¶

posts.name: John Naulty
posts.cooked:
@shellSignal
Actually, electron-builder makes it fairly painless to provide artifacts for a variety of linux distros.

Here‚Äôs a useful link of their docs

target = AppImage String | TargetConfiguration - Target package type: list of AppImage, snap, deb, rpm, freebsd, pacman, p5p, apk, 7z, zip, tar.xz, tar.lz, tar.gz, tar.bz2, dir.

The Signal-Desktop just need to make changes to their build/deployment pipeline. It can even be built with a multi-container platform it seems (reference: Multi Platform Build - electron-builder) which would work in travisCI too.

But to build locally with default comamnds, modify the targets produced in the packages.json file

posts.name: Arik
posts.cooked:
I think the main concern with downloadable builds, as elucidated by @moxie0 multiple times, is the lack of signature verification (or rather the need for manual signature verification) that reduces security for the average non-sha-summing non-gpg-signature-checking person.

This consideration alone eliminates the non-repo options.
IMHO an AppImage is a must have because it can be used everywhere. There is more than deb/rpm out there.
Signal is available as a flatpack. Flatpack is a cross platform packaging method.

Arch Linux now ships signal-desktop:

https://www.archlinux.org/packages/community/x86_64/signal-desktop/
